aws::graph::propositions: # World Health Organization Funding for Digital Healthcare Technology
The World Health Organization announced a $15 billion increase in funding for digital healthcare technology initiatives.
The $15 billion funding increase doubles World Health Organization's previous commitment.
The $15 billion funding increase represents the largest investment in health technology in the World Health Organization's history.
The funding will support artificial intelligence diagnostics.
The funding will support telemedicine platforms.
The funding will support innovative medical devices.
The innovative medical devices are designed to address healthcare disparities in underserved regions worldwide.
The initiative is called "Health Tech for All."
"Health Tech for All" will distribute funding over five years.
"Health Tech for All" will support 500 healthcare technology projects.
The 500 healthcare technology projects will be across 120 countries.
Priority areas include AI-powered diagnostic systems.
The AI-powered diagnostic systems can operate in resource-limited settings.
Priority areas include mobile health platforms.
The mobile health platforms provide medical consultations via smartphone.
Priority areas include low-cost medical devices.
The low-cost medical devices are designed for use in rural and remote areas.
Dr. Maria Santos is the WHO Director-General.
Dr. Maria Santos declared "Digital technology represents our best hope for achieving universal healthcare coverage."
Dr. Maria Santos made the announcement at the World Health Assembly in Geneva.
Dr. Maria Santos stated "These investments will ensure that a patient in rural Bangladesh has access to the same quality diagnostics as someone in London or New York."

metadata.header_path: /UN Health Agency Doubles Funding for Digital Healthcare Technology Initiatives/
/UN Health Agency Doubles Funding for Digital Healthcare Technology Initiatives/

text:
## News Report

The World Health Organization today announced a landmark $15 billion increase in funding for digital healthcare technology initiatives, doubling its previous commitment and representing the largest investment in health technology in the organization's history. The funding will support artificial intelligence diagnostics, telemedicine platforms, and innovative medical devices designed to address healthcare disparities in underserved regions worldwide.

The initiative, called "Health Tech for All," will distribute funding over five years to support 500 healthcare technology projects across 120 countries. Priority areas include AI-powered diagnostic systems that can operate in resource-limited settings, mobile health platforms that provide medical consultations via smartphone, and low-cost medical devices designed for use in rural and remote areas.

"Digital technology represents our best hope for achieving universal healthcare coverage," declared WHO Director-General Dr. Maria Santos during the announcement at the World Health Assembly in Geneva. "These investments will ensure that a patient in rural Bangladesh has access to the same quality diagnostics as someone in London or New York."
